item.description:
Cattail Harvest- Saturday, April 9, 1-3pm 

The cattail is a plentiful food source that was a staple for the native people of this area. Whether you are interested in supplementing regular dishes with a taste of the wild, becoming more intimate with nature, or surviving the collapse of the commercial food network, you should make acquaintance with the cattail.

Now is an appropriate time to harvest the rhizomes and sprouts. In this hands-on workshop we will dig up and collect cattail sprouts while discussing preparation methods. The facilitator will also explain how different parts of the cattail can be used at different times of the year for food and practical objects.

Jules Kobek is the co-founder of DIO (Do-It-Ourselves) Skillshare, facilitating workshops on skills of urban sustainability, such as sprouting, growing vegetables, and constructing raised garden beds. She also leads nature walks to identify edible weeds. After gathering urban wild food for several years, Jules has expanded her foraging to woodlands and marshes. She is studying ethnobotany- the study of the relationship between plants and people in different cultures- and is also learning wilderness survival skills.

In Arlington on the Minuteman Bicycle Trail near a bus stop.

$10-15 payable in cash at event.

Bring waterproof boots and a trowel or digging stick

Call 617-492-2340 by April 6 for registration, directions, and questions
item.how_to_find_us: Call 617-492-2340 by April 6 for registration, directions, and questions.
item.why: Cattail Harvest - Wild edibles and foraging for nature's super foods - a regular staple for health and sustainability and fun!
item.name: Wild Forage with Jules Kobeck
